dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey everyone, welcome back to the podcast. So, uh, we've been seeing a lot of headlines lately, right? Like, the Huawei CFO arrest, things like that, showing these ongoing skirmishes between the US and China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey everyone, welcome back to the podcast. So, uh, we've been seeing a lot of headlines lately, right? Like, the Huawei C F O arrest, things like that, showing these ongoing skirmishes between the U S and China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Frequent bilateral skirmishes will no doubt continue, as we saw with the arrest in early December of Huawei CFO Meng Wanzhou.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, absolutely, Host A. It feels like it's just one thing after another, doesn't it? But, you know, despite all that economic rivalry and, uh, political disagreement, some experts are saying a catastrophic outcome isn't actually *unlikely*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, absolutely, Host A. It feels like it's just one thing after another, doesn't it? But, you know, despite all that economic rivalry and, uh, political disagreement, some experts are saying a catastrophic outcome isn't actually unlikely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for all the economic rivalry and political disagreement between the United States and China, a catastrophic outcome is unlikely, so long as the US faces reality in three ways.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, interesting. So, not all doom and gloom then? But there are conditions, I imagine?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, interesting. So, not all doom and gloom then? But there are conditions, I imagine?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for all the economic rivalry and political disagreement between the United States and China, a catastrophic outcome is unlikely, so long as the US faces reality in three ways.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. The article we're looking at today says the US needs to, like, face reality in three key ways to avoid that worst-case scenario.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. The article we're looking at today says the U S needs to, like, face reality in three key ways to avoid that worst-case scenario.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But for all the economic rivalry and political disagreement between the United States and China, a catastrophic outcome is unlikely, so long as the US faces reality in three ways.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so what's the first reality we need to, um, confront?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so what's the first reality we need to, um, confront?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: For starters, accepting China's new normal as the world's largest GDP in purchasing-power parity terms. Just like the US dominated the 20th century, China's set to lead the 21st.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For starters, accepting China's new normal as the world's largest G D P in purchasing-power parity terms. Just like the U S dominated the twentieth century, China's set to lead the twenty first.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For starters, US policymakers need to accept the new normal of a China that boasts the worlds largest GDP (in purchasing-power parity terms). Just as the US was the largest economy in the twentieth century, China will be in the twenty-first.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Right, right. So, acknowledge the shift, but I mean, [Host B: *Yeah, exactly.*] the US will still be a major economic power, obviously. It's not like we're just disappearing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, right. So, acknowledge the shift, but I mean, the U S will still be a major economic power, obviously. It's not like we're just disappearing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But under any scenario, America will of course remain a major economic power.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's about acknowledging the new landscape. And that leads into the second point: the US really needs structural economic reforms at home.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's about acknowledging the new landscape. And that leads into the second point: the U S really needs structural economic reforms at home.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Second, the US must acknowledge the need for structural economic reforms at home, just as China did four decades ago, albeit with a very different focus and trajectory.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah. This is huge. Instead of just blaming, like, other countries for supposedly unfair trade practices, the US needs to look inwards, right? At its own unsustainable policies, deteriorating industrial capacity...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah. This is huge. Instead of just blaming, like, other countries for supposedly unfair trade practices, the U S needs to look inwards, right? At its own unsustainable policies, deteriorating industrial capacity...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Rather than blaming its huge trade deficit on other countries supposedly unfair trade practices, the US should consider its own unsustainable economic policies, deteriorating industrial capacity, and insufficient investment in infrastructure, education, and training.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh, and insufficient investment in things like infrastructure, education, and training. I mean, if policymakers keep just focusing on pleasing Wall Street, [Host A: *Yeah, and we see the results, don't we?*] we're going to see continued wealth inequality and social instability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh, and insufficient investment in things like infrastructure, education, and training. I mean, if policymakers keep just focusing on pleasing Wall Street, we're going to see continued wealth inequality and social instability.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If US policymakers keep focusing on pleasing Wall Street, big business, and neoliberal economists, then the countrys economic performance will suffer and wealth inequalities among Americans will continue to widen. This in turn will raise the risk of further social instability, extremism, and populism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's like, we ignored the subprime mortgage bubble, and look what happened. So, what's the third reality?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's like, we ignored the subprime mortgage bubble, and look what happened. So, what's the third reality?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US elites cannot afford to ignore obvious warning signs in the same way they overlooked the subprime mortgage bubble that triggered the 2008 financial crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: The third is, um, understanding China's geopolitical outlook and intentions better. Because, like, incorrect assessments here could really lead to unnecessary conflict.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The third is, um, understanding China's geopolitical outlook and intentions better. Because, like, incorrect assessments here could really lead to unnecessary conflict.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Finally, America needs a better understanding of Chinas geopolitical outlook and intentions an area where incorrect assessments may lead to unnecessary conflict.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: That's really crucial. Because a lot of Western theories would predict China's economic strength means it'll become this aggressive global power, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's really crucial. Because a lot of Western theories would predict China's economic strength means it'll become this aggressive global power, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, although Western theories of international relations predict that Chinas economic strength is bound to turn it into a dominant global power, the countrys history suggests otherwise.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but the article points out China's history actually suggests otherwise. It's never pursued aggressive geographical expansion, even when it had the power to.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but the article points out China's history actually suggests otherwise. It's never pursued aggressive geographical expansion, even when it had the power to.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China has never pursued aggressive geographical expansion, even when it had the power to do so.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: That's fascinating. And it mentions something called the "Doctrine of Mean," which basically says seeking world domination leads to national destruction. Plus, they were severely affected by imperialism themselves.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's fascinating. And it mentions something called the Doctrine of Mean, which basically says seeking world domination leads to national destruction. Plus, they were severely affected by imperialism themselves.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is consistent with an important classical teaching for Chinese emperors known as the Doctrine of Mean, which holds that attempts to seek world domination always lead to national destruction and bring misfortune to the people. In addition, China was severely affected by the imperialism and colonialism of other powers in the not-too-distant past and has no wish to repeat the experience.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. So what China *actually* wants is a fair and open global system, where everyone can participate equitably, and that encourages economic cooperation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. So what China actually wants is a fair and open global system, where everyone can participate equitably, and that encourages economic cooperation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: What China wants is a fair and open global system in which all can participate equitably and that encourages economic cooperation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, you know, makes sense. They still have their own internal challenges too, right? Like, needing to create jobs for a massive population, dealing with an aging society, and, uh, their tech reliance on imports.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, you know, makes sense. They still have their own internal challenges too, right? Like, needing to create jobs for a massive population, dealing with an aging society, and, uh, their tech reliance on imports.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, China must create enough jobs for the worlds largest working population, including eight million university graduates each year, even as it must also manage the burdens of an aging society...China relies heavily on imports of sophisticated goods for example, medical supplies from the West. And last years US ban on the sale of advanced semiconductor chips to telecom company ZTE, after the latter violated US export rules, clearly demonstrated Chinas technological inadequacy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. So, an ideological battle over economic models just isn't going to help anyone right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. So, an ideological battle over economic models just isn't going to help anyone right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In these testing times, an ideological battle over which economic development model is superior would benefit no one.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all. The US and China, as the two largest economies, really have a special responsibility to manage a peaceful transition to this new multipolar world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all. The U S and China, as the two largest economies, really have a special responsibility to manage a peaceful transition to this new multipolar world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the worlds two largest economies, the US and China have a special responsibility to manage a peaceful transition to a new multipolar international order.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It means cooperating, jointly managing challenges, and for the US, uh, realizing that trying to defeat or contain China economically won't solve its own problems.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It means cooperating, jointly managing challenges, and for the U S, uh, realizing that trying to defeat or contain China economically won't solve its own problems.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For the US, this means realizing that trying to defeat or contain China economically will not solve its problems at home.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Facing reality and accommodating China's rise is ultimately what's best for American national interests. It's a pragmatic view.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Facing reality and accommodating China's rise is ultimately what's best for American national interests. It's a pragmatic view.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Americas national interests would be far better served by facing reality and accommodating Chinas rise.
